objdescid.compdate: c. 1780-85The date is based on stylistic considerations.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Possibly acquired, from Blake or John Flaxman or John Linnell, by Thomas Chevalier (1767-1824); possibly Chevalier's great-granddaughter, Ellen M. Chevalier, later Mrs. William Dobinson; possibly sold from her collection, Sotheby's, 1 Dec. 1910, in lot 126 with eight other works (£3 to "Fry," probably acting for the dealer James Tregaskis); the dealer C. A. Stonehill; sold c. 1937 by Stonehill with a group of drawings by Flaxman and his associates to Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1943.

desc.objtitle:
Two Sketches of a Swordsman Standing Over His Defeated Opponent,
object 1 (Butlin 80 recto)

objnote.p: The reference to "Two Sketches" in the title includes a pencil drawing of the same subject and date on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a standing figure seen from behind appears to look down on another figure who supports himself on the ground with his right arm and leg. Both figures carry round shields and thus may be soldiers; the kneeling figure was likely just defeated. The central, standing figure may hold the hilt of a sword behind his back in his lowered right hand. Near the right edge of the drawing, a female(?) figure wearing a long gown stands facing forward and looks left. With both arms bent over her torso, she appears to hold or lead the horse at right that also faces forward. Above the kneeling soldier at left, a group of three figures who are drawn indistinctly stand behind what may be a wall or barrier extending across the scene horizontally. Additional indeterminate forms in the upper left quadrant may suggest tree trunks and perhaps hills.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the composition, a standing figure seen from behind appears to look down on another figure who supports himself on the ground with his right arm and leg. The upright figure who faces away and slightly left stands or walks with his left foot extended backward. He wears a short cloak with a hood and a hat and carries or holds a round shield. He may hold the hilt of a sword behind his back in his lowered right hand. It is likely that this figure is a soldier who just defeated the similarly armed reclining figure.

In the center of the composition, a standing figure seen from behind appears to look down on another figure who supports himself with his right arm and leg. The semi-reclining figure faces forward and right with head turned up and eyes closed. He appears to have short hair and perhaps a beard. With his left arm he holds or carries a round shield; his bent right arm is braced with his hand on the ground. He kneels on his bent right knee while his left is extended backward. It is likely that this figure is a soldier just defeated by the similarly armed standing figure.
The two soldiers, center and lower left, carry or hold round shields. The central, standing figure may hold the hilt of a sword behind his back in his lowered right hand.

Near the right edge of the drawing, a female(?) figure wearing a long gown stands facing forward and turns her head to look left, likely to watch the two central figures' actions. With her right arm bent and wrapped in front of her torso, she appears to hold or lead the horse at right. The figure's right foot appears to be slightly lifted off the ground, suggesting she may be walking forward.
To the immediate right of the standing female figure, a horse with a visible mane and forelock stands facing forward.

Above the kneeling soldier at left, a group of at least three, possibly four, figures who are drawn indistinctly stand behind what may be a wall or barrier. All appear to stand facing forward and may wear hats and possibly gowns.

On the left side of the drawing, a short wall or barrier extends horizontally across the middle of the composition. It appears to separate the group of three figures far left from the central soldiers.
Indeterminate forms in the upper left quadrant may suggest tree trunks and perhaps hills.
